title: Does water have gravity? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Oh but we can - in fact, water has multiple gravities. It has the most well known “make stuff go towards it” form of gravity, which according to our best theory (General Relativity) is actually caused by the bending of spacetime due to the presence of matter, such that “straight” lines actually become curved. Water is matter, and so curves spacetime in this way. But, it has another kind of gravity - “specific gravity” (SG). This is a word for relative density, where the relative-ness is usually (but not by definition) measured by comparison with pure water. Pure water has a “specific gravity” of 1.000 (SG is by convention measured to three decimal places), and sea water has an SG of around 1.025, meaning it is slightly more dense than pure water. In a purely poetic sense we could say that the sea has gravity, as it has been known to pull people towards it - the “Lure of the sea”, which for many people is quite strong. Also in a figurative sense, we could say that deep water, the sea in particular, has gravity in the sense that it is a serious subject: many people lose their lives at sea every year, and the sea is something which we must always take very seriously, no matter how experienced we are (in fact, the more experienced people tend to take it more seriously, having experienced the “gravity of the situation” first hand). So, there you go. That’s four reasons why we can say that water has gravity, and there may be more.

A small amount of water has almost no gravitational field. Nor does a small amount of dirt or a small rock. But, what gives an object a gravitational field is it's mass, so as the object's mass increases, it will have a higher gravitational field. You and I have gravitational fields, however small, similar to how water in space will have a gravitational field. But the fact is that it's mass is so relatively small compared to the earth and what's around it that other object's gravity severely overpowers it, thus giving it almost zero gravitational attraction.

Every body of matter has gravitation. Gravitational force may be small or large. In a scenario, a water drop in air attracts earth with the same force as the earth pulls the drop with. Mass of water is very less in contrast to the mass of earth, so water is accelerated more and moves faster. Earth also stirs, but very little. ‘Gravity’ is a special term to mean ‘gravitational force or gravitation by earth’.
